content.webTitle: And if you thought skiing in Dubai was odd ...

fields.headline: And if you thought skiing in Dubai was odd ...
fields.bodyText: Iran Where Dizin, in the Alborz Mountains, about two hours' drive north of the capital, Tehran. When December until just after the Iranian New Year (21 March). Weekends (in Iran that's Thursday and Friday), see Tehran's cool, nouveau-riche hit the slopes. What's hot World-class powder up to 10ft deep, thanks to the altitude (3,350m) and the resort's north-facing slopes. Fantastic Persian food. Cheap - a day pass for the 12 lifts serving the 16 runs costs $4. Off-piste guide: $5-$6 per day. What's not Men and women have to use separate slopes and lifts. Women must cover up their head and body. Après scene is a blast, if a hookah pipe and bed by 9pm floats your boat. How to Persian Voyages (www.persianvoyages.com; 01306 885894) offers an eight-day ski and sightseeing tour to Iran from £1,050pp, including the ski resorts of Dizin and Shemshak and the world-heritage site of Isfahan. Price includes full-board in four-star hotels and return BA flights. Morocco Where Oukaimeden, in the Atlas Mountains, 46 miles from Marrakesh. When Snow conditions are a big, big gamble, but mid-January to mid-February is the best bet. What's hot Well, Africa for a start, so the chance to ski in a T-shirt should not be sniffed at. When conditions are good, there are up to 13 miles of runs served by seven lifts. When they are bad, there are always the spectacular views of the mountains. What's not Donkeys as ski-lifts brings a new twist to landing on your ass. There are few decent places to stay at the resort, so base yourself in Marrakech. How to Best of Morocco (www.realmorocco.com; 01380 828533) has five nights half-board at the stylish Caravanserai Hotel in Marrakesh from £550pp, including return BA flights from Gatwick. Lebanon Where Faraya Mzaar, 30 miles from Beirut. When Mid-January to March. What's hot The heavy snow storms in February mixed with warm air from the Med create superb powder. Midweek, you'll have the resort's 40 runs practically to yourself - unheard of in the Alps. Legendary Lebanese hospitality. Breathtaking views over the Bekaa Valley. What's not The quietness midweek means the party scene may be pretty tame - although the weekends can be lively. Runs are mainly intermediate level or below. Tension in the region makes checking the Foreign Office website essential. How to BMed (0870 850 9850; www.flybmed.com) flies to Beirut from £388.30 including taxes. Skileb (00 961 323 6623) has a seven-day package including transfers, B&B in a three-star hotel, ski rental, ski pass, three après-ski excursions to Byblos, Harissa and Jeita Grotto, entrance fees and guide for around US$780 pp. South Korea Where Bears Town, one-and-a-half hour's drive from the capital, Seoul. When Same season as Europe. What's hot Being based in the megalopolis that is Seoul. Friendly Koreans. The potent national drink, soju. Inept local skiers who make intermediates feel like Franz Klammer. What's not Inept local skiers who terrify intermediates. Megabucks for everything from equipment hire to meals. Korean pop music blasting from loudspeakers. Short slopes. How to The Marriott Renaissance Seoul (www.marriott.com; 0800 221222) has rooms from $130pp per night between 15 December and 28 February. Price includes transfers to Bears Town and 30 per cent discount for ski passes. BA (0870 850 9850; www.ba.com) flies to Seoul from £684.60 including taxes.
